resources.string: Care Counts
Settings
Ways Women Win
Common Questions
Get Insurance
Your healthcare plan must cover breastfeeding comprehensive support and counseling from trained providers, and access to breastfeeding supplies, for pregnant and nursing women.
Your healthcare plan must cover breast cancer mammography screenings every 1 to 2 years for women over 40.

Your healthcare plan must cover contraception: Food and Drug Administration-approved contraceptive methods, sterilization procedures, and patient education and counseling, as prescribed by a health care provider for women with reproductive capacity (not including abortifacient drugs). This does not apply to health plans sponsored by certain exempt "religious employers".
Your healthcare plan must cover breast cancer chemoprevention counseling for women at higher risk.
Your healthcare plan must cover anemia screening on a routine basis for pregnant women.
Your healthcare plan must cover cervical cancer screening for sexually active women.
Your healthcare plan must cover chlamydia infection screening for younger women and other women at higher risk.
Your healthcare plan must cover breast cancer genetic test counseling (BRCA) for women at higher risk for breast cancer.
Your healthcare plan must cover domestic and interpersonal violence screening and counseling for all women.
Your healthcare plan must cover folic acid supplements for women who may become pregnant.
Your healthcare plan must cover gestational diabetes screening for women 24 to 28 weeks pregnant and those at high risk of developing gestational diabetes.
Your healthcare plan must cover gonorrhea screening for all women at higher risk.
Your healthcare plan must cover Hepatitis B screening for pregnant women at their first prenatal visit.
Your healthcare plan must cover HIV screening and counseling for sexually active women.
Your healthcare plan must cover Human Papillomavirus (HPV) DNA test every 3 years for women with normal cytology results who are 30 or older.
Your healthcare plan must cover osteoporosis screening for women over age 60 depending on risk factors.
Your healthcare plan must cover Rh Incompatibility screening for all pregnant women and follow-up testing for women at higher risk.
Your healthcare plan must cover Sexually Transmitted Infections counseling for sexually active women.
Your healthcare plan must cover syphilis screening for all pregnant women or other women at increased risk.
Your healthcare plan must cover tobacco-use screening and interventions for all women, and expanded counseling for pregnant tobacco users.
Your healthcare plan must cover urinary tract or other infection screening for pregnant women.
Your healthcare plan must cover well-woman visits to get recommended services for women under 65.

resources.string: Common Questions

string-array.name: QandA
string-array.item: Why should I have health coverage?
No one plans to get sick or hurt, but most people need medical care at some point. Health insurance covers these costs and protects you from very high expenses.
https://www.healthcare.gov/why-should-i-have-health-coverage/
Can children stay on a parent’s plan until age 26?
If a plan covers children, they can be added or kept on the health insurance policy until they turn 26 years old.
https://www.healthcare.gov/can-i-keep-my-child-on-my-insurance-until-age-26/
What are my birth control benefits?
Plans in the Health Insurance Marketplace must cover contraceptive methods and counseling for all women, as prescribed by a health care provider.
https://www.healthcare.gov/what-are-my-birth-control-benefits/
What if I\'m pregnant or plan to get pregnant?
If you\'re uninsured and pregnant you may be turned down, charged a higher premium, or have benefits excluded until 2014. Until then, Medicaid and CHIP may help.
https://www.healthcare.gov/what-if-im-pregnant-or-plan-to-get-pregnant/
What if I have a pre-existing health condition?
Starting in 2014, most health insurance plans can\'t refuse to cover you or charge you more just because you have a pre-existing health condition.
https://www.healthcare.gov/what-if-i-have-a-pre-existing-health-condition/
Do Marketplace insurance plans cover mental health and substance abuse services?
All Marketplace insurance plans cover mental health and substance abuse services as an essential health benefit.
https://www.healthcare.gov/do-marketplace-insurance-plans-cover-mental-health-and-substance-abuse-services/

resources.string: Select a Topic
Next
Back
Español
Healthcare Call

To apply for coverage, you will need the following:


-Social Security Numbers (or document numbers for legal immigrants)

-Employer and income information for every member of your household who needs coverage (for example, from pay stubs or W-2 forms--Wage and Tax Statements)

-Policy numbers for any current health insurance plans covering members of your household

-A completed Employer Coverage Tool (provided on the site)

Unfortunately, the call option is not available on the system you are using currently.*


*This may be due to it being a tablet. Please use a phone to use this option.

Please note how many children and adults you would like on your plan.

Gather medical information for each member including:

-Birth records for all members

-History of diseases

-History of smoking

-Information on all hospital visits in the past year

Before applying for coverage you should:

-Check if you can get lower costs on coverage by using the Cost Calculator button.

-Obtain the information for the Employer Coverage Tool to see if you are qualified through an employer. Download this form by clicking on the Coverage Tool button

Now that you have all the information ready, there are two ways to apply for health insurance:

The first method is by calling 1-800-318-2596 or 1-855-889-4325 using the call button below.
The second way to apply is by visiting the website using the button below. Thank you for using our app!\n\n
Call Now
Go to Website
Cost Calculator
Coverage Tool
Share This
